prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Resolution/spatial setup: The larger spatial scales are covered with our Cycle 1 observations combining the ACA to recover the extended emission and the 12m-array to reach a resolution of 1.1''. In the current proposal we apply for 0.2'' resolution. The new data will be combined with the Cycle 1 data to produce high-resolution, high-fidelity images. The previously known companion is at 2.7'', but at 0.2'' (=30 AU) resolution we will have the possibility to resolve the spiral pattern produced by a debated closer companion within the disk seen in the Cycle1-ACA data (Fig.1), as well as the closer binary pair. We also aim to constrain the short-term time variability of the mass-loss process and variations in the mass loss and expansion velocity will be traceable as small-scale density variations across the extent of the emission. To cover the same extent as the lower resolution data of our Cycle 1 proposal (25"x25") we need a 10 pointing mosaic.
Correlator setup: The source will be observed in the 12CO(3-2) line at 345.796 GHz. We have chosen the center frequency so that the 13CO(3-2) line at 330.588 GHz is covered in the lower sideband. The 12CO/13CO ratio is expected to be ~35 in this source and we expect to probe gas structures and emission also in this line. In some cases, the lower optical depth of the 13CO-line will be beneficial when probing bright optically thick (in 12CO) structures. We have also added two continuum bands at 333.1 and 343.3 GHz, respectively. The continuum emission will probe the dust and allow us to precisely determine the position of the star.
Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is based on our ALMA-ACA observations on this source from Cycle 1. The peak flux with the ACA is 2.8 Jy/beam, which corresponds to 10 mJy/beam at the requested resolution assuming a smooth brightness distribution. At the requested resolution we will probe the most compact, very brightest features which will be 5-10 times brighter (based on our previous results on R Sculptoris). Taking the conservative approach, assuming that the emission will be 5 times brighter, we aim for a S/N of 15 at 2 km/s (the line is expected to be 80 km/s wide).

Resolution/spatial setup: The larger spatial scales are covered with our Cycle 1 observations combining the ACA to recover the extended emission and the 12m-array to reach a resolution of 1.1''. In the current proposal we apply for 0.2'' resolution. The new data will be combined with the Cycle 1 data to produce high-resolution, high-fidelity images. At 0.2'' resolution we will resolve the binary pair at 0.46'' separation (20) and can study the overflow in close detail. We also aim to constrain the short-term time variability of the mass-loss process and variations in the dust density distribution on the order of 0.3'' have been detected close to this source (16). Variations in the mass loss and expansion velocity will be traceable as small-scale density variations across the extent of the emission. To cover the same extent as the lower resolution data of our Cycle 1 proposal (25"x25") we need a 10 pointing mosaic.
Correlator setup: The source will be observed in the 12CO(3-2) line at 345.796 GHz. We have chosen the center frequency so that the 13CO(3-2) line at 330.588 GHz is covered in the lower sideband. The 12CO/13CO ratio is expected to be ~20 in this source and we expect to probe gas structures and emission also in this line. In some cases, the lower optical depth of the 13CO-line will be beneficial when probing bright optically thick (in 12CO) structures. We have also added two continuum bands at 333.1 and 343.3 GHz, respectively. The continuum emission will probe the dust and allow us to precisely determine the position of the star.
Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is based on our previous APEX CO(3-2) observations of this source (21). The peak flux at APEX is 173 Jy/beam, which corresponds to 20 mJy/beam at the requested resolution assuming a smooth brightness distribution. At the requested resolution we will probe the most compact, very brightest features which will be 5-10 times brighter (based on our previous results on R Sculptoris). Taking the conservative approach, assuming that the emission will be 5 times brighter, we aim for a S/N of 30 at 2 km/s (the line is expected to be 40 km/s wide).

Resolution/spatial setup: The larger spatial scales are covered with our Cycle 1 observations combining the ACA to recover the extended emission and the 12m-array to reach a resolution of 1.1''. In the current proposal we apply for 0.2'' resolution. The new data will be combined with the Cycle 1 data to produce high-resolution, high-fidelity images. At 0.2'' resolution we will resolve the binary pair at 0.6'' (22) and be able to study the overflow in close detail. We also aim to constrain the short-term time variability of the mass-loss process and monotoring of the dust emission close to this source are consistent with dust shells being expelled with a 12 yr period, corresponding to variations on the order of the requested resolution. Variations in the mass loss and expansion velocity will be traceable as small-scale density variations across the extent of the emission. To cover the same extent as the lower resolution data of our Cycle 1 proposal (25"x25") we need a 10 pointing mosaic.
Correlator setup: The source will be observed in the 12CO(3-2) line at 345.796 GHz. We have chosen the center frequency so that the 13CO(3-2) line at 330.588 GHz is covered in the lower sideband. The 12CO/13CO ratio is expected to be ~8 in this source and we expect to probe gas structures and emission also in this line. In some cases, the lower optical depth of the 13CO-line will be beneficial when probing bright optically thick (in 12CO) structures. We have also added two continuum bands at 333.1 and 343.3 GHz, respectively. The continuum emission will probe the dust and allow us to precisely determine the position of the star.
Sensitivity: The requested sensitivity is based on our ALMA-ACA observations on this source from Cycle 1. The peak flux with the ACA is 8.7 Jy/beam, which corresponds to 27 mJy/beam at the requested resolution assuming a smooth brightness distribution. At the requested resolution we will probe the most compact, very brightest features which will be 5-10 times brighter (based on our previous results on R Sculptoris). Taking the conservative approach, assuming that the emission will be 5 times brighter, we aim for a S/N of 15 at 1 km/s (the line is expected to be 10 km/s wide).

Resolution/spatial setup: The larger spatial scales are covered with our Cycle 1 observations combining the ACA to recover the extended emission and the 12m-array to reach a resolution of 1.1''. In the current proposal we apply for 0.5'' resolution. The new data will be combined with the Cycle 1 data to produce high-resolution, high-fidelity images. At 0.5'' resolution we will still not be able to resolve the binary pair at 55 mas separation, but based on our SPH models of the overflow in this particular source, we will be able to put strong constraint on eccentricity of the orbit (current estimates range from 0.25-0.8; 23,24) through detailed information on the velocity structure, as well as by constraining the expected density enhancements on the periastron side of the orbit. We will also be able to constrain the size of the void with ionized material surrounding the hot companion thereby attaining crucial information on its nature. We also aim to constrain the short-term time variability of the mass-loss process and variations in the mass loss and expansion velocity will be traceable as small-scale density variations across the extent of the emission. Since the star is more distant, the same physical size as that of pi Gru can be mapped within the primary beam of 18" and no mosaic is necessary for this source.
Correlator setup: The source will be observed in the 12CO(3-2) line at 345.796 GHz. We have chosen the center frequency so that the 13CO(3-2) line at 330.588 GHz is covered in the lower sideband. The 12CO/13CO ratio is expected to be ~15 in this source and we expect to probe gas structures and emission also in this line. In some cases, the lower optical depth of the 13CO-line will be beneficial when probing bright optically thick (in 12CO) structures. We have also added two continuum bands at 333.1 and 343.3 GHz, respectively. The continuum emission will probe the dust and allow us to precisely determine the position of the star.
Sensitivity: For our Cycle 1 proposal we estimated a very lowest limit on the CO(3-2) emission of 3 mJy at 18" based on CO(1-0) and (2-1) emission from the IRAM 30m (19) and radiative transfer modelling assuming an extended source. It is likely that the molecular extent of this source is determined by high-energy processes and much more confined than in this estimate. At the requested resolution we will probe the most compact, very brightest features and based on our SPH model (Fig 2) and previous results on R Sculptoris we aim for an rms of 0.7 mJy at 0.5" and 6 km/s resolution (the line is expected to be 50 km/s wide).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The required conditions for stars to evolve into planetary nebulae continue to puzzle, but it is likely that interaction with a companion is needed to explain the observed morphologies. In Cycle 1 we attempt to test this hypothesis by observing a sample of binary AGB stars. The sample covers a decisive range in binary separation and the influence of the companion on the large-scale structure on the AGB wind will be tested. For Cycle 2, we propose to add the longer baselines, not offered in Cycle 1, to probe even smaller structures. The binary pairs will be resolved and the influence of the companion on the mass-loss process will be determined by probing cavities around hot companions, arcs and clumps resulting from varying mass loss. ALMA is the only facility with the necessary sensitivity and resolution to study the effects of binary interaction systematically. The data will be analysed using 3D radiative transfer and compared to 3D SPH models of the gravitational interaction. By constraining how the mass is lost and the shaping effects during this important transitional phase, we believe that major advances in the study of late stellar evolution will be made.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00524.S , Shaping the Outflows of Binary AGB Stars, Sofia Ramstedt
